Vintage market days coming to Clay County in December Events to feature antique dealers, vintage-inspired artisans, local artists and more Carianne Luter , Digital Media & Engagement Manager Kara Pound , Old City Public Relations Published: August 31, 2022 at 12:55 PM Tags: December , Vintage market , events , Clay County , Green Cove Springs Vintage market in Clay County (YANITZA NINETT ,  YANITZA NINETT PHOTOGRAPHY) CLAY COUNTY, Fla. – Just in time for holiday shopping, Vintage Market Days Jacksonville is coming to our area! The three-day event will bring more than 120 unique, vintage-inspired vendors to one place. Shoppers will be able to purchase anything from homemade candles and home décor to vintage furniture, original artwork, clothing, and much more. Recommended Videos The events will be held Friday, Dec. 2 through Sunday, Dec. 4 at the Clay County Fairgrounds in Green Cove Springs. “Just over six years ago, I was a healthcare director in Richmond, Indiana and recently diagnosed with breast cancer,” explained Tonya Ross, the owner of Vintage Market Days (VMD) Jacksonville, a franchise under the VMD umbrella. “I was sitting in chemo treatment and saw an article about Vintage Market Days. I didn’t hesitate and joined VMD in 2016. A year ago, I moved to St. Augustine and now manage the Jacksonville and Dayton-Cincinnati markets. Sometimes we endure hardships to find the direction our life is supposed to take.” The events will provide a special holiday time shopping experience complete with visits from Santa Claus! The three-day event will provide a special holiday time shopping experience complete with visits from Santa Claus! Dates and times: Friday, Dec. 2 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Saturday, Dec. 3 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., and Sunday, Dec. 4 from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Admission: Children under 12 will get in free. Cash and credit cards are accepted at the gate. Once purchased, tickets are good for re-entry into the event all weekend. Learn more about early shopping opportunities and ticket purchases here. “There will also be live music, food trucks and more family-friendly attractions on-hand at this year’s market,” said Ross. “It’s a fun community event that really showcases the talented artisans and makers this region has to offer. We can’t wait to see everyone there!” Click here for more information. Vintage Market Days Jacksonville presents "Celebrate With Us" December 2-4 Copyright 2022 by WJXT News4JAX - All rights reserved. Advertise in our e-newsletter Search form Search Secondary menu 101 Family Day Trips Around Jacksonville Farmers Markets Festivals in the Jacksonville area Vintage Market Days presents "Let the Good Times Roll" *The event has already taken place on this date: Sun, 05/05/2024 Vintage Market Days is an upscale vintage-inspired market featuring original art, antiques, clothing, jewelry, handmade treasures, home décor, outdoor furnishings consumable yummies, seasonal plantings and a little more. The Market is a three day event held several times a year in various communities. Each Vintage Market Days event is a unique opportunity for vendors to display their talents and passions in different venues throughout the country. The Market will also provide the customer with a very special shopping experience.  We absolutely love the thought of bringing the Vintage experience to both vendors and customers throughout the country! Please help us keep this calendar up to date! If this activity is sold out, canceled, or otherwise needs alteration, email mindy@kidsoutandabout.com so we can update it immediately. If you have a question about the activity itself, please contact the organization administrator listed below. Event Hours & Admissions Friday, May 3, 2024 Early Buying Event 10:00 am to 4:00 pm Saturday, May 4, 2024 General Admission 10:00 am to 4:00 pm Sunday, May 5, 2024 General Admission 10:00 am to 4:00 pm Admission for children under 12 is free. Cash and credit card are accepted at the gate. Once purchased, your ticket is good for re-entry into the event all weekend. *Times, dates, and prices of any activity posted to our calendars are subject to change. Please be sure to click through directly to the organization’s website to verify. Southwest Orlando, Orlando 988.7 mi $273.99 $268.99 -2% Medieval Torture Museum Explore the Medieval Torture Museum with the Admission Tickets 177 North State Street, Chicago 0.4 mi $45.07 $36.27 -20% 4.7 (636) How to reach us © MapTiler © OpenStreetMap contributors Vintage Market Days of Jacksonville 884.9 mi 2497 Florida 16, Green Cove Springs, FL 32043 Closed Directions About Vintage Market Days of Jacksonville Vintage Market Days organizers Amy Scott and Dianna Brown discovered an interest in vintage bazaars at a young age. As a child, Dianna frequented neighborhood garage sales to find items that she repurposed into decorations for her "pretend house." Meanwhile, Amy visited the Tulsa Flea Market with her mother and great-aunt, who collected Depression glassware and helped her start her own vintage collections. As adults, Amy and Dianna organize upscale vintage events several times a year at indoor and outdoor locations throughout Oklahoma. In turn, franchisees have brought these shopping extravaganzas to at least eight other states. Shoppers can examine architectural salvage, peruse vintage home-decor items, or drape themselves in clothing and jewelry from yesteryear so they won't stand out as a tourist on time-traveling trips. And to complement the vintage wares, vendors also sell original art and handmade jewelry. Riverside Arts Market tries to build on success News Sports Entertainment Lifestyle Opinion Advertise Obituaries eNewspaper Legals NEWS Riverside Arts Market tries to build on success After a big first year, organizers are looking for how to improve. Charlie Patton When the Riverside Arts Market opened for business last April 4, everybody was amazed as an estimated 40,000 people came together under the Fuller Warren Bridge. "It was pretty stunning," said Tony Allegretti, the market's executive director. He called the success a "perfect storm" of talent, a great riverfront venue and free admission. Equally surprising to many was that people kept coming every Saturday for nine months. More than half-a-million people - an average of 15,000 a week - visited during the 38 weeks of operation, he estimated. Now the question people are asking is: Will those crowds be back when the market reopens Saturday after a two-month hiatus? Plenty of effort is going into accomplishing that. For one thing, the market has become much more selective about which vendors it will accept, Allegretti said. The emphasis is on local handmade arts and crafts when choosing who can rent the 158 vendor booths, about 100 of which will be occupied by artists. "The art committee has been very stringent," Allegretti said. Meanwhile, Wayne Wood, a member of the market's steering committee, has planned what he calls the world's Shortest Big Parade to open Saturday's market. Wood promises the parade will include jugglers, clowns, belly dancers, dogs in costume and the Raines High School marching band. City Councilman Michael Corrigan will be grand marshal. The parade will arrive in the market shortly after 10 a.m. Visitors will find a mix of vendors, as well as an assortment of street entertainers. There will be traditional artists like Gloria Danvers, who returns for a second year selling handmade jewelry. "It's a first-class venue," she said. "It was perfectly planned." About 40 vendors will be selling food products. "The thing that's so exciting is the move toward buying local," said Jay Burnett, owner of Bold Bean Coffee Roasters, who is also a returning vendor. "... You get to know the people who are producing your food." There also will be a new section known as the Fringe. Among the off-beat vendors Allegretti has lined up are surfboard shapers, a bicycle-maker and a man who builds made-to-order stereos. The Jacksonville Public Library's Zine collection will be featured in the Fringe section. A year ago, the nearby Cummer Museum supported the market but didn't really appreciate the impact it would have, said Hope McMath, the Cummer's executive director. This year, the Cummer is not only actively involved in the market but plans to take advantage of the presence of so many art lovers in the neighborhood, she said. Directional signs will be placed prominently so visitors are aware the Cummer is just a block away. Meanwhile, Cummer reps will be in the crowd, handing out coupons good for $4 off the $10 admission fee to the museum. The market's success has been "really thrilling," McMath said. "It's made the arts accessible for everyone ... It breaks down the elitist barrier around art." The market makes money off booth rentals and sponsorships, Allegretti said. Last year it had a $250,000 budget and finished the year with a $40,000 net profit. As a result, they've lowered booth rentals slightly this year, he said. charlie.patton@jacksonville.com, (904) 359-4413 Careers Staff Directory Accessibility Sitemap Legals Public notice certification Our Ethical Principles USA TODAY Network Style Guide Responsible Disclosure Subscription Terms & Conditions Advertiser Acceptance Policy Terms of Service Privacy Policy California Notice at Collection Your Privacy Choices Contact Us Support Local Business Advertise Your Business Promote your Event Buy and Sell Licensing & Reprints Legal Notices Help Center Subscriber Guide Manage Account Give Feedback Subscribe Today Newsletters Facebook X Instagram eNewspaper NIE Jobs Real Estate Classifieds Pay Your Ad Bill Shopping 10BEST LocaliQ Digital Marketing Solutions © 2025 www.jacksonville.com. About Us — Rusted a Vintage Market (904) 398-1523 info@rustedavintagemarket.com Facebook Instagram Facebook Instagram About Us Contact Us Select Page About Us Learn more about Rusted A Vintage Market. Rusted: A Vintage Market came about when a group of people got together to sell old things.  As time has progressed, we at Rusted have become friends and in many ways function as a large family. We genuinely care for one another and try to work as one unit.  Each vendor brings their own particular style to our vintage store.  We enjoy reusing, reinventing, and restoring older items to make them usable in the 21 century home. Our store brings items that fit into the farmhouse, boho, garden, primitive and industrial styles of today’s homes. We are a one stop shopping experience for those looking for a special accent piece of furniture to smaller decorative items such as baskets, dishes and one of a kind antique pieces. At Rusted: A Vintage Market , we strive to create a comfortable shopping atmosphere where the coffee is always hot and the wine is often flowing!  We are open Monday through Saturday 10-6 and Sunday 1-5. Location & Store Hours 1523 San Marco Blvd. Jacksonville, FL 32207 (904) 398-1523 Store Hours: Monday – Saturday 10 – 6 Sunday 1 – 5 Connect On Facebook Get Updates First Name Last Name Email address: Leave this field empty if you're human: About Us Contact Us Facebook Instagram Copyright © 2019 Rusted a Vintage Market
